Anything used externally leads your body to stop produce that thing as it goes on. Our body produces only what requires. Even the hypertrophy works the same way, where in your brain feels the need of more cellular density. So goes for strength, hunger, blood, chemicals etc. The essence of necessity is all that has lead to this whole evolution of not only humans but also every other life. We’ve gained new things and lost quite a few. It’s all about what the brain things we need. With a decent nutrition, continuous hard work and proper rest, and pushing yourself to a point where we need more testosterone, can definitely intrigue the brain to produce more testosterone. And yes, even when you are older. The thing is we seldom push to the limits, or for that matter, through the limits. When you can’t do what is required and still trying, that’s the time your brain decides to intervene. That’s how body works. No matter how much you talk about calories, protein and workout, it’s the brain at the end that is the engineer. You’d need to get hold of your brain, and convince it to do stuff. That’s when you are doing it as a human. Otherwise there are numerous animals who can do the physical stuff far far better.

The overall point is that for every ease of work, or for a shortcut taken, you have to compromise with your strength, skill, potency, capabilities and what not which you would require to avail that otherwise. Please do not use EST unless you have reached to best you could and you are competing for the best of the bests. Yes steroids can do it much easily, much quicker and with least of efforts. But you’ll be paying quite some prices unknowingly. Your body will forever rely on it. Works for every drug.

It has always seemed to me that beyond some of the more well known negative effects, steroids are something that can technically be used in a somewhat balanced way but the trouble for me is that in order to continuously reap the benefits you need to be continuously taking them so you become dependent on them, that may be fine for some but to me the question is what if I can no longer take them or I can no longer acquire them? My philosophy is ideally to be as reliant on as few things as possible. Food, water, and air are things that we are all inherently dependent on, but consider an addicted smoker; they HAVE to spend money and time to acquire nicotine because their body is dependent on it or it drives them nuts. If you want to shortcut it to get bigger muscles because you seek the positive feedback from being exceptionally muscular and lean then you have to deal with the trade-off of becoming a slave to this substance, in order to keep getting that positive feedback you have to keep using it. It all depends on your philosophy as to whether or not using steroids is worth it.

Personally I just put the drive for being muscular and athletic towards working out the slow, hard way, and granted I am not big at all, and sometimes it is easy to sense the appeal of using steroids (also I definitely could be eating and working out far smarter) but I cannot find the justification in my own life to have to introduce another reliance that steroids would be. Funny enough my cousin once asked me if I was on steroids and I thought he was joking lol but he was young, just starting high-school, and I have been pretty 'cut' for a long time (pretty lean and lots and lots of pull ups) but any serious lifter would say I am scrawny which is totally fair, the best description I've heard for me that makes sense is 'wiry'. I think if I just ate more I probably could get pretty big but whatever, I'll get to it when I get to it (see: probably never lol).

Also a side comment on people who said steroid-users must be insecure, I would say there is a good chance that's true but in my mind it is often the insecurities that push us to supreme levels of things, as an insecurity makes us either completely avoid something or try to contain and deal with it. If you asked a massive body builder if he's big or sculpted enough, despite what he might say, I would wager he is never satisfied. Satisfaction leads to complacency and complacent people do not strive for excellence (whatever that 'excellence' may be - think of anorexic people too as another extreme example). The best athletes look for the holes in their game and work on them, the brightest minds don't focus on the things they know but the questions they still have unanswered, I think you can find a way to look at most things people do as an attempt to avoid or contain an insecurity, to avoid negative feedback. To me life is a perpetual cycle of sensing insecurities and seeking to contain them which can give some brief positive feedback, but it can never last. We are in a constant avoidance of negative feedback because as an organism this is the only way to survive since it would make sense that the root of all negative feedback is death.

There are diminishing returns once you reach what would be your natural genetic limit for muscular development. What you do after you reach that point is what separates the men from the boys. Taking steroids and lifting to build muscle past your genetic limit is much harder than being natural. It requires every piece of the puzzle to be in order. Diet, training, supplementation, drugs, and sleep necessarily have to be tuned to a very extreme/mentally taxing degree. 4,000+ calories a day, 4-5+ injections pre-comp a day, a million little tablets to swallow, needing to sleep 10+ hours while on massive doses of tren, on top of grueling workouts that a natural athlete couldn't hope to copy. Anabolic steroids increase the rate of protein synthesis, so your muscles heal much more quickly. When you're trying to build supernatural amounts of muscle, you have to train a supernatural amount of times per week. Unfortunately, your tendons and ligaments don't heal at the same rate as your muscle tissue, which greatly increases your chances of becoming injured. The amount of pain an "enhanced" athlete has to endure dwarfs that of natural lifters as a result of this. All of these things can be done relatively safely while under the supervision of a doctor. Steroids are relatively benign when used by someone who knows what they're doing and is making an effort to maintain a healthy lifestyle. Steroids are PEDs, not recreational drugs. They were developed to build you up, not tear you down. The most dangerous drugs a bodybuilder takes are diuretics, insulin, designer peptides, thyroid medication, and DNP, not anabolic steroids. Anabolic steroids generally have to be abused for a long period of time before any deletrious side effects appear. If you regularly get blood work, flobotomies, plan proper HRT cycles that maintain sexual function, and get regular physical exams from a medical doctor, then I wouldn't be too worried.
